Award.AwardTitle: CSR: Small:The Wisconsin Specialized Support for Storage Clouds (WiS3C) Project

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: The increasing importance of ?big data?, i.e., the usage of computer systems to store and analyze large data sets, is changing the face of both science and industry. Underlying big-data analyses are big-data storage systems, including the popular Hadoop File System (HDFS). The WiS3C project seeks to re-examine the core foundations of storage systems such as HDFS, specifically by developing new specialized storage techniques to improve both the reliability and performance of these systems. The project specifically targets novel modifications in crash consistency (i.e. how storage systems keep data safe despite power loss), end-to-end data integrity (i.e., how storage systems ensure data does not become corrupt), and caching and layout (i.e., how storage systems make access to data fast); the sum of these changes will result in a new era of more robust and high-performance big-data analysis. The project will also improve the educational pipeline by connecting more undergraduates with research and attracting more women into the Ph.D. program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The world of computer storage is increasingly driven by the cloud, as large companies, institutions, and other organizations move their IT infrastructures into rented services instead of self-hosted systems. In this project, we have focused on analyzing existing cloud-based systems as well as developing new critical technologies to enable better performance and higher reliability of this essential piece of infrastructure. 

The contributions of this work have been manifold. For example, we have shown how existing cloud-based systems have critical flaws that can lose important data, and have shown what key pieces must be developed in order to avoid such data loss. We have also analyzed existing large-scale storage systems, showing the inefficiencies in their designs, as well as techniques for streamlining their performance. We have developed new techniques to provide important features that are needed in a shared cloud infrastructure which are not currently provided by existing systems. Finally, we have developed new techniques to improve the performance of modern storage systems, in some cases by more than an order of magnitude. 

As society increasingly relies on data in all aspects of its function, it is essential that the storage systems that store said data be robust, correct, and provide high performance at low cost. The work performed on this project has helped move the state of the art forward in all of these regards.
